byline.original: By SHAILA DEWAN and ANDREW W. LEHREN

abstract: New York Times examination finds pretrial intervention, program meant to spare low-risk offenders criminal record and relieve overcrowded American courts and jails, is unaffordable for many; district attorneys have total discretion as to fees charged for program, also known as diversion, turning it into money-maker that is often out of reach for poor offenders (Series: No Money, No Mercy).

headline.print_headline: Spared From a Criminal Record, as Long as You Can Pay
headline.main: After a Crime, the Price of a Second Chance

snippet: A program called diversion was supposed to spare low-level offenders the ruinous consequences of a criminal record. Then money got in the way....
lead_paragraph: A program called diversion was supposed to spare low-level offenders the ruinous consequences of a criminal record. Then money got in the way.
